I see. It's possible that you may have experienced a traumatic event that caused your symptoms, such as a head injury or a near-drowning. It's also possible that you may have a medical condition that is causing your symptoms, such as a seizure disorder or a brain tumor.

I would like to refer you to a neurologist for further evaluation. They will be able to perform tests to determine the cause of your symptoms and recommend appropriate treatment.

In the meantime, it's important to avoid any activities that could trigger another seizure or make your symptoms worse. This may include avoiding loud noises, bright lights, and any activities that cause you to feel anxious or stressed.

Can you tell me more about your recent past? Do you remember anything unusual happening before you were found unconscious?
I don't remember anything unusual happening before I was found unconscious.

I see. It's possible that you may have experienced a sudden and unexpected seizure, which can sometimes occur without any warning signs or symptoms. This is known as an "unprovoked seizure."

It's important to follow up with a neurologist to determine the cause of your seizure and to rule out any other potential causes, such as a brain tumor or infection. They may recommend further testing, such as an MRI or CT scan, to help identify the cause of your seizure.

In the meantime, it's important to take steps to protect yourself and prevent any further seizures. This may include avoiding any activities that could trigger another seizure, such as driving or operating heavy machinery, and taking medication as prescribed by your doctor to help prevent seizures.

Can you tell me more about your family medical history? Have any of your close relatives had a history of seizures or other neurological conditions?

Cardiac arrest occurs when the heart stops functioning properly and is not able to pump blood to the body. This can be caused by a variety of factors, including heart disease, electrical problems with the heart, and drug or alcohol use.

I will continue to monitor your vital signs and perform additional tests to confirm the diagnosis and determine the cause of your cardiac arrest.
